title: Onondaga County Legislature adopts 2016 budget with lower property taxes, more amphitheater oversight
text:
Onondaga County Legislature adopts 2016 budget with lower property taxes, more amphitheater oversight 2013-03-05-ctyleg4.JPG Comments 
SYRACUSE, N.Y. - The Onondaga County Legislature on Tuesday unanimously approved a $1.263 billion spending plan for 2016 that includes a decrease in the property tax rate and more oversight of the new Onondaga Lake amphitheater. 
Mahoney proposed a $1.266 billion budget for 2016 that also would have lowered property taxes, but would have increased the sewer rate by $20 per unit. 
The Legislature dropped the proposed sewer rate increase and lowered the property tax rate even more. 
The Legislature is still calculating the property tax rate for each municipality. Check back for updates. 
As part of the budget process, the Legislature made a point of asserting its oversight of spending at the new amphitheater. 
The Legislature put half of the amphitheater's proposed $1.9 million budget in a contingency account, to be released as 2016 progresses. 
The Legislature also unanimously passed a resolution that requires Mahoney's staff to report on the amphitheater's finances at least three times a year. 
Legislature Chairman Ryan McMahon, R-Syracuse, said it is unlikely the Legislature would deny any funding. But said the move ensures regular updates as Mahoney hires companies to manage and promote the new concert venue. 
Legislator Kevin Holmquist, R-Manlius, said it is the most important thing the Legislature will do next year. 
"The role that we'll play will set the tone," he said. 
The Legislature also added to Mahoney's proposed budget: $100,000 to manage the overpopulation of deer and spread of Lyme disease in neighborhoods that apply for funding. McMahon has already started a task force to study whether to bait and cull the deer in his own neighborhood, the Greater Winkworth area. He said the response could be different in each neighborhood. 
$500,000 for demolition of properties taken for redevelopment by the Greater Syracuse Land Bank. $300,000 to expand the Dolly Parton Imagination Library, which provides free books to enrolled children under 5 years old.
